page.title: 13LANDSCAPE AND BUILDINGS CONT
page.content: buildings of the Guernsey pattern (see photograph)with outbuildings of the same stone.The older houses may have been thatched at one time,now they are roofed with slate or tiles.The later houses follow the same pattern but use dressed stone and are more English in design.The outbuildings are now converted to dwellings,the thick walls pierced for windows and the great doors blocked up.The nearer to St Peter Port the closer together are the houses in a disorganised mixture of styles harmonized by surviving granite walls and earthbanks.Plain early 19th century villas with touches of the Gothic revival in the shape of the windows,stand near later Edwardian houses with roof pinnacles,stained glass door pannels and wooden fretwork round the steep gables.In between,in plots which become smaller as the
